supply_logistics.supply_status: Adequate for training operations. Division arrived May 1941 from East Africa and began desert acclimatization. Supply lines from Alexandria (280km) adequate for defensive operations. Primary constraints: water supply in desert training areas, adjustment from East African tropical conditions to desert environment.

weather_environment.terrain_type: coastal plain and rocky desert (Western Desert, Egypt)

subordinate_units.composition: 1st Transvaal Scottish, 1st Duke of Edinburgh's Own Rifles, 1st Royal Natal Carbineers
subordinate_units.status: Arrived Egypt from Massawa on 12 June 1941

subordinate_units.composition: 1st Cape Town Highlanders, 1st Natal Mounted Rifles, 1st Field Force Battalion, 2nd Field Force Battalion
subordinate_units.status: Arrived Egypt from Berbera on 8 June 1941; reassigned to 2nd SA Division by end of Q2

subordinate_units.composition: 3rd Transvaal Scottish, 1st South African Irish, 2nd Botha Regiment
subordinate_units.status: Arrived Egypt with Division HQ on 3 May 1941

subordinate_units.composition: 7th, 8th, 9th Field Batteries; converted to 25-pounders in August 1941

tactical_doctrine.role: Infantry Division - Training and acclimatization phase Q2 1941. Transitioning from East African tropical warfare to Western Desert mechanized warfare.
special_capabilities: Experienced in East African mountain and tropical warfare
Veteran of successful Italian East Africa campaign (1940-1941)
High morale from recent victories at El Wak, Juba, Combolcia, Amba Alagi
known_issues: Adjustment period from East African to desert conditions
Equipment transition: 18-pounder guns being replaced with 25-pounders in August 1941
Phased arrival: brigades arriving May-June 1941, not fully assembled until mid-June
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Division undergoing desert training at Mersa Matruh, constructing defensive works, learning mechanized warfare tactics. Water management and vehicle maintenance in sandy conditions major training focus.

scenario_suitability: Not suitable for Q2 1941 combat scenarios (first combat November 1941 at Sidi Rezegh)
special_rules: High morale from East African victories
Reduced effectiveness in mobile desert operations until trained
Full combat effectiveness from Operation Crusader (November 1941) onward
historical_engagements: East African Campaign: Juba River crossings (February 1941)
Western Desert: Operation Crusader - Sidi Rezegh (November 1941, outside Q2)

source: South African Military History Society - samilhistory.com (Tier 2)
British Military History - britishmilitaryhistory.co.uk PDF document (Tier 1)
samilitaryhistory.org - 5th SA Brigade at Sidi Rezegh (Tier 2)
defenceweb.co.za - Natal Carbineers and Natal Mounted Rifles fact files (Tier 2)
known_gaps: Exact brigade commander names (1st and 5th Brigades) - moderate confidence
Chief of Staff name - not available in Tier 1/2 sources
Precise equipment variant counts for trucks and support vehicles - estimated from divisional establishments
Individual battery/company commander names - not available in sources
Exact operational vehicle counts vs total - estimated at 90-95% operational for newly arrived division
Staff strength numbers estimated from British Commonwealth divisional establishments
4.5-inch howitzer count estimated (9th Field Battery converted to howitzers January 1941)
notes: Commander: Maj-Gen George Brink commanded 1st SA Division in Q2 1941; Dan Pienaar commanded 1st SA Brigade, promoted to Division command March 1942
2nd SA Brigade arrived 8 June 1941 but was reassigned to 2nd SA Division by end of Q2 1941
Artillery conversion: 3rd Field Regiment (THA) had 18-pounders in Q2 1941, converted to 25-pounders in August 1941 (Q3)
Division not in combat Q2 1941 - training phase at Mersa Matruh after arrival from East Africa
Total personnel 16,500 is typical for Commonwealth infantry division establishment 1941
Q2 1941 status: Phased arrival May-June, training and acclimatization, defensive works construction
All Wikipedia sources excluded per project requirements
